Award.AwardTitle: Telescope Array TAX4 Upgrade Deployment Proposal
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cosmic rays are highly energetic sub-atomic particles from space that travel at velocities near the speed of light. The origin and acceleration mechanism for ultra-high energy cosmic rays, which likely come from extreme astrophysical phenomena outside our galaxy, are currently unknown. The Telescope Array (TA) is the largest cosmic ray detector in the northern hemisphere. Located outside Delta, Utah, and representing a joint US-Japanese effort, TA was designed to study the nature and origin of the highest energy particles in the Universe. This award to the University of Utah supports the US contribution to an expansion of the experiment, designated TAx4, which will significantly increase the collecting area of the observatory. With new capabilities, TAx4 will probe an apparent anisotropy, or "hotspot," observed in the northern hemisphere that may represent a local source of ultra-high energy cosmic rays. The enlarged TAx4 will also help to address differences in the results from TA in the northern hemisphere and the Pierre Auger Observatory in the southern hemisphere. This award will also support the University of Utah group's involvement in the Astrophysics Science Project Integrating Research and Education (ASPIRE) program, which engages area teachers, students, and the public through visits to schools and a web site of science lessons designed around the curricula of schools in Utah and neighboring states. The group will also host associated experiments in other fields that benefit from the TA location and infrastructure.

TAx4 will enlarge TA by a factor of four. Japanese TA collaborators will build the scintillation counters of the TAx4 surface detectors. The University of Utah group is responsible for deploying the surface detectors in two areas in Millard and Juab Counties, and then building two fluorescence detectors to overlook the two TAx4 surface detector areas. The project will be implemented in phases while TA continues to operate and collect data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is the construction of the TAx4 extension to the Telescope Array experiment. This will increase the high energy cosmic ray aperture of the Telescope Array by about a factor of four.

Our collaborators plan to add about 500 new scintillator detectors on a 2.08km=1.3mi square grid to the present Telescope Array (with its 1.2km=0.75mi spacing). The detectors sample the density of secondary particles reaching the Earth from the shower of particles induced when a cosmic ray collides with the atmosphere. They will also measure the footprint at the surface and determine the arrival direction of the cosmic rays to search for sources.  The larger spacing will mean that this part of the detector will focus on the highest energy cosmic rays - those with energies greater than a few times 10^19eV.

The University of Utah's part of this expansion is to add new telescopes to view the sky above these detectors as well as to assist our collaborators with their parts of the project.  Observing the scintillation light from the air shower, one can determine the energy, chemical composition, and origin direction of the primary cosmic ray.  The main contributions due to the new telescopes are: a) calibration of the new scintillator detectors and b) performing a hybrid measurement of the highest energy events observed in those areas for more precise reconstruction of events as well as cosmic ray composition measurement via the Xmax technique.

While Telescope Array and Auger agree that the composition of cosmic rays is light, likely protonic, between 10^18 and 5x10^18 eV, at higher energies their interpretations of the data diverge. Telescope Array continues to observe a light, consistent with protonic, composition to the highest energies. Meanwhile, the composition determined by the Auger collaboration, looks heavier and heavier above 5x10^18 eV. The Auger composition interpretation starts to mix in He thern Carbon, Nitrogen and Oxygen and heavier elements at ratios that depend upon the model used. TAx4 will enable the Telescope Array collaboration to collect additional events at these highest energies and better test the reasons for the divergence in interpretation.

In order to reduce the cost of the project, the telescopes are only planned to view 3-17 degrees above horizon. Therefore, they will only observe enough of the shower profile to make a composition measurement for distant high energy events. This is, however, the region which can most benefit from increased event statistics.

As of the conclusion of this construction project (August 2019), the 12 new telescopes to be installed by the University of Utah have been installed. The northern telescopes have largely been operational since June 2018.  The first data has been analyzed and a first pass at a spectrum has been made.  The southern telescopes were more recently installed and are still in commissioning. 

The first 260 scintillator detectors have been installed in the late winter of 2018-19 as soon as US Bureau of Land Management (BLM) was granted.   About half of the detectors are deployed in the north and half in the south as well as three communications towers in the north and three in the south. The detectors are presently being commissioned.   

The new experimental apparatus will soon be producing physics results.
